protocol_name: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
protocol_name_html: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
before_start: • Make sure you are using fresh E. coli cells streaked for isolation on LB + antibiotics no more than 1 week from -80°C cryostock.

groups.group_name: Protist Research to Optimize Tools in Genetics (PROT-G)

components.data: Grow the diatom culture to mid-log phase (≈ 8.0E6 cells/ml for Phaeodactylum tricornutum grown on F/2 media or 5.0 E7 cell/ml when grown on BG-11). We have investigated transformation efficiency throughout the growth curve and found this to be the sweetspot.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Grow the diatom culture to mid-log phase (≈ 8.0E6 cells/ml for Phaeodactylum tricornutum grown on F/2 media or 5.0 E7 cell/ml when grown on BG-11). We have investigated transformation efficiency throughout the growth curve and found this to be the sweetspot.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation
source_data.protocol_name: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.protocol_name_html: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.annotation:
-  The original protocol plated the culture (250uL of 1.0E8 cells/ml) on 1/2 strength L1, 1% agar plates for 4 days prior to transformation.

 

-  We have been investigating liquid cultivation because many diatom species do not survive on agar.
source_data.thread_text:
-  The original protocol plated the culture (250uL of 1.0E8 cells/ml) on 1/2 strength L1, 1% agar plates for 4 days prior to transformation.

 

-  We have been investigating liquid cultivation because many diatom species do not survive on agar.
source_data.body:
-  The original protocol plated the culture (250uL of 1.0E8 cells/ml) on 1/2 strength L1, 1% agar plates for 4 days prior to transformation.

 

-  We have been investigating liquid cultivation because many diatom species do not survive on agar.

comments.affiliation: Harvard Medical School, Department of Systems Biology | UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) | J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI)
comments.name: Jernej Turnsek
comments.comment_text: I'd like to stress that L1 reported in the Karas et al. paper contains 5x more N (NaNO3) and P (NaH2PO4 H2O) than the one on the NCMA website. There are also some other minor deifferences between both formulations, but this is the major one. Higher N and P are apparently very important for the conjugation protocol. That said, I've had success with f/2-based selection plates as well.
comments.body: I'd like to stress that L1 reported in the Karas et al. paper contains 5x more N (NaNO3) and P (NaH2PO4 H2O) than the one on the NCMA website. There are also some other minor deifferences between both formulations, but this is the major one. Higher N and P are apparently very important for the conjugation protocol. That said, I've had success with f/2-based selection plates as well.

comments.affiliation: Harvard Medical School, Department of Systems Biology | UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) | J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI)
comments.name: Jernej Turnsek
comments.comment_text:
In my experience there is quite some flexibility when it comes to Pt plating before conjugation. It works even if you plate just one day before conjugation. See also Diner et al. (2016) for more details on how to adjust the amount of plated Pt cells in this case.

 

R. E. Diner, V. A. Bielinski, C. Dupont, A. E. Allen, P. D. Weyman, Refinement of the Diatom Episome Maintenance Sequence and Improvement of Conjugation-based DNA Delivery Methods, doi:10.3389/fbioe.2016.00065.
comments.body:
In my experience there is quite some flexibility when it comes to Pt plating before conjugation. It works even if you plate just one day before conjugation. See also Diner et al. (2016) for more details on how to adjust the amount of plated Pt cells in this case.

 

R. E. Diner, V. A. Bielinski, C. Dupont, A. E. Allen, P. D. Weyman, Refinement of the Diatom Episome Maintenance Sequence and Improvement of Conjugation-based DNA Delivery Methods, doi:10.3389/fbioe.2016.00065.

comments.affiliation: Harvard Medical School, Department of Systems Biology | UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) | J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI)
comments.name: Jernej Turnsek
comments.comment_text: In case you decide to plate Pt, it is OK to plate on LB-containing 1/2xL1 plate and later on just add donor suspension directly to plated diatoms. That works just fine too in my experience.
comments.body: In case you decide to plate Pt, it is OK to plate on LB-containing 1/2xL1 plate and later on just add donor suspension directly to plated diatoms. That works just fine too in my experience.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation
source_data.protocol_name: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.protocol_name_html: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.annotation:
Cultivation Conditions

 

-  Cultivation in 0.2 um-filtered L1 or BG-11 media prepared using 32ppt seawater collected from the Gulf of Mexico.

-  80 - 100 μmol photons m-2 s-1 provided by Philips Daylightt Delux 40 watt T12 flourscent tubes.

-  Semi-continuous operation in 1L bubble column bioreactors (500 - 800 ml working volume).

-  0.2 μm filtered air containing 1% CO2 provides aeration/agitation at 0.2 vvm.
source_data.thread_text:

-  Cultivation in 0.2 um-filtered L1 or BG-11 media prepared using 32ppt seawater collected from the Gulf of Mexico.

-  80 - 100 μmol photons m-2 s-1 provided by Philips Daylightt Delux 40 watt T12 flourscent tubes.

-  Semi-continuous operation in 1L bubble column bioreactors (500 - 800 ml working volume).

-  0.2 μm filtered air containing 1% CO2 provides aeration/agitation at 0.2 vvm.
source_data.body:
Cultivation Conditions

-  80 - 100 μmol photons m-2 s-1 provided by Philips Daylightt Delux 40 watt T12 flourscent tubes.

-  Semi-continuous operation in 1L bubble column bioreactors (500 - 800 ml working volume).

-  0.2 μm filtered air containing 1% CO2 provides aeration/agitation at 0.2 vvm.

components.data: Grow 1 mL of E. coli culture containing both the mobillity plasmid (Pta-MOB) and carrier plasmid, overnight (16-20 hrs) in LB+antibiotics, for each planned transformation. (We grow them at 37°C at 270 rpm in a shaking incubator.)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Grow 1 mL of E. coli culture containing both the mobillity plasmid (Pta-MOB) and carrier plasmid, overnight (16-20 hrs) in LB+antibiotics, for each planned transformation. (We grow them at 37°C at 270 rpm in a shaking incubator.)

source_data.annotation: In my experience it has proven beneficial to perform conjugations with multiple donors carrying THE SAME construct. 2/3 worked beautifully, one failed completely.
source_data.thread_text: In my experience it has proven beneficial to perform conjugations with multiple donors carrying THE SAME construct. 2/3 worked beautifully, one failed completely.

source_data.affiliation: Harvard Medical School, Department of Systems Biology | UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) | J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI)

components.data:
On the day of transformation, use the overnight culture to inoculate 50 mL of fresh LB+antibiotic, 1:50 dilution, for each planned transformation.

  • Grow to an OD600 of 0.8 - 1.0 (37°C with 270 rpm shaking).
  • This takes about 3-4 hours.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
On the day of transformation, use the overnight culture to inoculate 50 mL of fresh LB+antibiotic, 1:50 dilution, for each planned transformation.

  • Grow to an OD600 of 0.8 - 1.0 (37°C with 270 rpm shaking).
  • This takes about 3-4 hours.

comments.affiliation: Harvard Medical School, Department of Systems Biology | UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) | J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI)
comments.name: Jernej Turnsek
comments.comment_text: I had success with donor OD600 as little as 0.15. I didn't expect any colonies, but to my surprise the outcome was similar to other donors with more "normal" OD600.
comments.body: I had success with donor OD600 as little as 0.15. I didn't expect any colonies, but to my surprise the outcome was similar to other donors with more "normal" OD600.

comments.affiliation: Harvard Medical School, Department of Systems Biology | UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) | J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI)
comments.name: Jernej Turnsek
comments.comment_text: I grow 25 mL donor bacteria on the day of conjugation and resuspend pellet in 150 uL SOC. The total cell suspension volume will still be around ~250 uL due to some minor LB leftover.
comments.body: I grow 25 mL donor bacteria on the day of conjugation and resuspend pellet in 150 uL SOC. The total cell suspension volume will still be around ~250 uL due to some minor LB leftover.

components.data:
For each transformation, centrifuge 50 mL of E. coli culture and the required Phaeodactylum tricornutum volume at 4000 x g for 10 minutes at 4°C.

 

  • Resuspend E. coli pellet in 500 μL of SOC medium.
  • Resuspend P. tricornutum pellet in 500 μL of L1 medium.

 

 

Note: The diatom and E. coli cultures should be centrifuged at around the same time to minimize the amount of time they spend concentrated.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
For each transformation, centrifuge 50 mL of E. coli culture and the required Phaeodactylum tricornutum volume at 4000 x g for 10 minutes at 4°C.

 

  • Resuspend E. coli pellet in 500 μL of SOC medium.
  • Resuspend P. tricornutum pellet in 500 μL of L1 medium.

 

 

Note: The diatom and E. coli cultures should be centrifuged at around the same time to minimize the amount of time they spend concentrated.

source_data.annotation: The original protocol scraped the agar plates the culture was initiated on using 500uL F/2, then adjusted the volume to attain 5.0 E8 cells/ml. We have found no difference so far in transformation effficiency between liquid- and plate-initiated cultures.
source_data.thread_text: The original protocol scraped the agar plates the culture was initiated on using 500uL F/2, then adjusted the volume to attain 5.0 E8 cells/ml. We have found no difference so far in transformation effficiency between liquid- and plate-initiated cultures.

components.data:
In a 1.5 mL tube mix 200 μl of E. coli cells with 200 μl of Phaeodactylum tricornutum cells.

 

Negative control:   In a 1.5 mL tube mix 200 μl of SOC medium with 200 μl of Phaeodactylum tricornutum cells.

 

Note: Incubate and treat the negative control plates identically to conjugation plates.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
In a 1.5 mL tube mix 200 μl of E. coli cells with 200 μl of Phaeodactylum tricornutum cells.

 

Negative control:   In a 1.5 mL tube mix 200 μl of SOC medium with 200 μl of Phaeodactylum tricornutum cells.

 

Note: Incubate and treat the negative control plates identically to conjugation plates.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 5 of Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation
source_data.protocol_name: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.protocol_name_html: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.annotation:
-  The authors of The original protocol suggested spreading the mixture near, but not touching, the edges of the plate, as this mixture will be scraped and replated in 2 days.

 

-  N concentration seems to be important.  We have found greater transformation success in using 0.5x BG-11 medium made with seawater instead of 0.5x L1 medium.

 

-  5% LB is a sufficient concentration to support the E. coli culture without encouraging growth.  Increasing the LB concentration results in increased algal death.  We have also buffered the media but that did not increase P. tricornutum survivorship.
source_data.thread_text:

-  5% LB is a sufficient concentration to support the E. coli culture without encouraging growth.  Increasing the LB concentration results in increased algal death.  We have also buffered the media but that did not increase P. tricornutum survivorship.
source_data.body:
-  The authors of The original protocol suggested spreading the mixture near, but not touching, the edges of the plate, as this mixture will be scraped and replated in 2 days.

 

-  N concentration seems to be important.  We have found greater transformation success in using 0.5x BG-11 medium made with seawater instead of 0.5x L1 medium.

 

-  5% LB is a sufficient concentration to support the E. coli culture without encouraging growth.  Increasing the LB concentration results in increased algal death.  We have also buffered the media but that did not increase P. tricornutum survivorship.

components.data: Collect cells by adding 1 mL of L1 medium. Use a cell scraper to concentrate cells and medium to one side of the plate. Transfer resuspended cells to a 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube with a P1000 pipette and filter tips.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Collect cells by adding 1 mL of L1 medium. Use a cell scraper to concentrate cells and medium to one side of the plate. Transfer resuspended cells to a 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube with a P1000 pipette and filter tips.

components.name: Section

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 6 of Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation
source_data.protocol_name: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.protocol_name_html: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.annotation:
It is important to use filter tips as smalll peices of agar that are accidentaly scraped up can cause the pipette to cavitate resulting in contamination.

 

We will often first add 500uL to collect the majority of the cells from the plate into the 1.5mL tube, then repeat with an additional 500ul to collect the remainder.

comments.comment_text: In my experience it is possible to collect ~700 uL total from 1 mL L1.
comments.body: In my experience it is possible to collect ~700 uL total from 1 mL L1.

components.data:
After a minimum of 8-12 days, untransformed Phaeodactylum tricornutum cells die off, and colonies of transformed cells begin to appear – in some cases, this can take 3-4 weeks.

 

 

Alternatively selection can be done in liquid BG-11 Selection media using eGFP as a reporter and sorted using FACS.

 

un-transformed Pt

 

eGFP  expression

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 13 of Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.protocol_name: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.protocol_name_html: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.annotation:
-   For plate selection, use ImageJ protocol for colony enumeration.

 

-   Calculate transformation efficeincy using:

Efficiency = (number of colonies on plate) ÷ (selection volume cell density (cell/mL) x volume (mL) put on selection plate)

 

Note: Be sure to include a dilution factor in the calculation if it was used in plating or counting!

-   Calculate transformation efficeincy using:

Efficiency = (number of colonies on plate) ÷ (selection volume cell density (cell/mL) x volume (mL) put on selection plate)

 

Note: Be sure to include a dilution factor in the calculation if it was used in plating or counting!

comments.affiliation: Harvard Medical School, Department of Systems Biology | UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) | J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI)
comments.name: Jernej Turnsek
comments.comment_text: I'm surprised there's no autofluorescence signal in the WT control. I am observing autofluorescence to be a persisting issue. Could you please share the exact conditions that led you to this image? And the eGFP sequence itself - both nucleic acid and protein sequence? Thank you very much!
comments.body: I'm surprised there's no autofluorescence signal in the WT control. I am observing autofluorescence to be a persisting issue. Could you please share the exact conditions that led you to this image? And the eGFP sequence itself - both nucleic acid and protein sequence? Thank you very much!

comments.affiliation: Harvard Medical School, Department of Systems Biology | UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) | J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI)
comments.name: Jernej Turnsek
comments.comment_text:
I am observing 2 different colony morphologies on my selection plates - one corresponding to predominantly fusiform and the other to oval morphotype. See an example on the link below. Note how small the colonies are even after ~2 weeks on selection plates. It is most likely because the lack of N and P --> in this particular example I used f/2-based plates and not 1/2xL1 which are more optimal. 

 

http://openwetware.org/images/d/d0/16_10_19_Pt_exconjugant_colony_morphologies.pdf
comments.body:
I am observing 2 different colony morphologies on my selection plates - one corresponding to predominantly fusiform and the other to oval morphotype. See an example on the link below. Note how small the colonies are even after ~2 weeks on selection plates. It is most likely because the lack of N and P --> in this particular example I used f/2-based plates and not 1/2xL1 which are more optimal. 

 

http://openwetware.org/images/d/d0/16_10_19_Pt_exconjugant_colony_morphologies.pdf

source_data.protocol_name_html: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.annotation:
-  The authors of The original protocol suggested spreading the mixture near, but not touching, the edges of the plate, as this mixture will be scraped and replated in 2 days.

 

-  N concentration seems to be important.  We have found greater transformation success in using 0.5x BG-11 medium made with seawater instead of 0.5x L1 medium.

 

-  5% LB is a sufficient concentration to support the E. coli culture without encouraging growth.  Increasing the LB concentration results in increased algal death.  We have also buffered the media but that did not increase P. tricornutum survivorship.

-  N concentration seems to be important.  We have found greater transformation success in using 0.5x BG-11 medium made with seawater instead of 0.5x L1 medium.

source_data.protocol_name_html: Full Contact Microbiology (a.k.a Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation)
source_data.annotation:
-   Dilution of the selection volume (using L1 as makeup volume) can help facilitate colony enumeration if 200μl results in too many colonies.

 

-   To maximize the number of colonies the entire volume of resuspended cells can be plated to multiple plates.

 

-   Collect 1 μL  of the cell suspention and dilute 1:1000 for FlowCam cell count.
source_data.thread_text:
-   Dilution of the selection volume (using L1 as makeup volume) can help facilitate colony enumeration if 200μl results in too many colonies.

 

-   To maximize the number of colonies the entire volume of resuspended cells can be plated to multiple plates.

 

-   Collect 1 μL  of the cell suspention and dilute 1:1000 for FlowCam cell count.
source_data.body:
-   Dilution of the selection volume (using L1 as makeup volume) can help facilitate colony enumeration if 200μl results in too many colonies.

 

-   To maximize the number of colonies the entire volume of resuspended cells can be plated to multiple plates.

 

-   Collect 1 μL  of the cell suspention and dilute 1:1000 for FlowCam cell count.

components.data: Incubate at 18°C and 100 μmol photons m-2 s-1 until colonies appear.

components.data: During the 3-4 hours the E. coli culture is growing, measure the Phaeodactylum tricornutum cell concentration with a FlowCam or haemocytometer to calculate the required volume needed to collect 2.5E8 cells for each transformation.
